definitions.definition: to send something from your hand through the air by moving your hand or arm quickly
definitions.sensetop: throw somethingthrow something + adv./prep.throw something to somebodythrow somebody something

examples.text: Practise throwing and catching.
They had a competition to see who could throw the furthest.
Who threw that rock?
Stop throwing stones at the window!
She threw the ball up and caught it again.
He threw the ball into the bushes and the dog ran to fetch it.
Three grenades were thrown into the corridor.
Two petrol bombs had been thrown through the front window.
Don't throw it to him; give it to him!
Can you throw me that towel?

definitions.definition: to put something in a particular place quickly and carelessly

examples.text: Just throw your bag down over there.
He threw the keys casually down on the table.
A blanket was thrown over the bed.
I took some folders and started throwing stuff in them.

definitions.definition: to move something/somebody suddenly and with force

examples.text: The boat was thrown onto the rocks.
The sea throws up all sorts of debris on the beach.
They were thrown to the floor by the impact.
He was arrested and **thrown in jail** *(= sent to prison)*.
He threatened to throw her in the river if she screamed.
I threw open the windows to let the smoke out.
He threw the double doors open in a dramatic gesture.
Miraculously he was thrown clear *(= out of the vehicle when it crashed)* and suffered nothing more than severe bruising.
The ship's cargo was thrown overboard.
We were literally thrown out of our bunks.

definitions.definition: to move your body or part of it quickly or suddenly

examples.text: He threw back his head and roared with laughter.
I ran up and threw my arms around him.
Jenny threw herself onto the bed.
I just wanted to throw myself into his arms and cry.

definitions.definition: to make somebody fall quickly or violently to the ground

examples.text: Two riders were thrown *(= off their horses)* in the second race.

definitions.definition: to make somebody/something be in a particular state
definitions.sensetop: be thrown out of somethingbe thrown into something

examples.text: Hundreds were thrown out of work.
The future of the project has been **thrown into doubt**.
Everything was **thrown into chaos**.
We were thrown into confusion by the news.
The problem was suddenly thrown into sharp focus.
to throw doubt on the verdict
to throw the blame on someone
to throw accusations at someone
He threw the question back at me *(= expected me to answer it myself)*.

definitions.definition: to make somebody feel upset, confused, or surprised

examples.text: The news of her death really threw me.
The speaker was completely thrown by the interruption.

definitions.definition: to roll a dice or let it fall after shaking it; to obtain a particular number in this way

examples.text: Throw the dice!
He threw three sixes in a row.

definitions.definition: to make a clay pot, dish, etc. on a potter’s wheel

examples.text: a hand-thrown vase

definitions.definition: to send light or shade onto something

examples.text: The trees threw long shadows across the lawn.

definitions.definition: to make your voice sound as if it is coming from another person or place
to hit somebody with your fist
to move a switch to operate something
to have a sudden period of angry behaviour, violent emotion, etc.

examples.text: She'll **throw a fit** if she finds out.
Children often **throw tantrums** at this age.
They threw a party for him on his birthday.
He always throws a big bash on Oscar night.

definitions.definition: to deliberately lose a game or contest that you should have won

examples.text: He was accused of having thrown the game.

wordOrigin: Old English thrāwan ‘to twist, turn’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch draaien and German drehen, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin terere ‘to rub’, Greek teirein ‘wear out’. The current senses which express propulsion and sudden action, date from Middle English.
